awd_titl_txt: Collaborative proposal:  The foundation of terrestrial life: Inferring a total-evidence timeline of vascular plant evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will determine when vascular plants evolved and how they are related. Vascular plants include lycopods, ferns and their allies, as well as conifers and flowering plants. They form the foundation of nearly all terrestrial ecosystems and our food supply, yet scientists disagree about when and how they evolved. Current methods for estimating evolutionary timelines for these species have led to conflicting answers, as they rely on the ability of researchers to assign extinct fossil species correctly to particular branch points in the tree of life. This assignment is challenging to do because extinct species may have morphology that can be interpreted differently. Researchers will refine a new data analysis method to address this limitation. They will compare the DNA sequences of living vascular plants and incorporate morphological data from both living and extinct species to reconstruct their evolutionary relationships. During this process, researchers will apply new computer algorithms to estimate the evolutionary timeline for the species. Researchers will train undergraduate and graduate students, including members of under-represented groups, and support the professional development of an early-career researcher. They will educate the public about plant evolution by creating an interpretive exhibit at the University of California Berkeley and by producing a series of online video lessons for high school students and educators.

This project will develop a new total-evidence dating method to reconstruct the next generation of time-calibrated phylogenetic hypotheses that incorporate both extinct and extant species. Researchers will leverage DNA sequence data collected by an existing NSF award to reconstruct a backbone phylogeny of ca. 300 extant vascular plants using nuclear genomic data. They will also collect morphological data for ca. 300 traits from these species as well as ca. 200 extinct fossil species. These data will be simultaneously integrated by the software program RevBayes to infer a time-calibrated phylogeny. This program combines sophisticated tree-shape priors, powerful models of morphological evolution, and recently developed methods for relaxing the molecular clock. Project outcomes will include a robust estimate of vascular plant divergence times and patterns of morphological evolution with an explicit measure of the full associated uncertainty of that estimate. The project will support research by sharing new and legacy morphological datasets in the online, open-access PROTEUS database and by hosting a training workshop focused on refining the theory and practice of divergence-time dating. Research will strengthen collaborations among US and international scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Inferring the timescale of evolution across deep time—when did particular groups of organisms, particular functional traits, or particular ecological interactions evolve—is a challenging problem. The fossil record provides critical information about organisms that existed in the past, but synthesizing that information with information about the tree-of-life is full of technical and practical difficulties. The vascular plants (e.g., lycopods, ferns, conifers, and flowering plants) form the foundation of terrestrial life and also have a rich fossil record, making them a particularly useful group with which to evaluate these methods of “time tree” estimation, as well as being a group for which a robust timescale of evolution would be exceptionally helpful for understanding the origins of Earth’s biological richness.

 

In this project we formed a multidisciplinary team of botanists, computational biologists, and paleontologists to develop and test new methods for inferring time trees, and then to apply those methods to infer a timescale for vascular plant evolution. We discovered that recently developed methods that simultaneously infer the timescale of evolution, the patterns of morphological change, and the tree of life outperform the “classical” sequential approach. Specifically, our inferences suggest that similarities between ancient organisms and ones living today can be superficial and the result of the independent evolution of similar features; it is only by modelling the process of morphological change and the timescale simultaneously that this pattern can be revealed. This result calls into question the conclusions of many earlier studies that applied the classical approach. A secondary result of our research is that many groups of organisms with so-called “primitive” features may actually be recently evolved rather than relics of the evolutionary past. In the course of this research, we also made some fundamental contributions to the statistical foundation of these types of analyses. In particular, we discovered that standard tools to test evolutionary hypotheses—for example, whether rates of speciation and extinction have varied over time—are not theoretically valid and should be avoided, and have identified valid alternatives. Taken together, our research provides a foundation for the reliable and testable inference of deep evolutionary timescales, providing evolutionary biologists with important tools for understanding the origins of Earth’s biota.


In conjunction with these research accomplishments, we produced four educational videos, tailored for the K – 12 curriculum. Two of them (“How Did Plants Change Our Planet?” and “How did past climate change influence today’s plants?”) explore plant evolution in deep time and the impacts of plants on terrestrial life, and two of them (“How Do Scientists Work Together” and “How do scientists explore the past?”) focus on the practice of science and the tools that scientists are able to use to understand the past. These videos were followed by a five-week workshop oriented to graduate students and other researchers, where we provided a deep-dive into the complicated world of time-tree estimation. In addition, we are finishing a display garden in the UC Berkeley science atrium that showcases plant diversity through a curated selection of living plants and accompanying displays describing plant evolution through time. This area is frequented by the public, including school groups, so provides a valuable opportunity to have a major impact on education related to the origin and importance of plants.
